history.content:
EE16AB are there to get you started, but a pair of freshman-oriented courses can't possibly do the work of an entire degree and what realistically requires some further serious apprenticeship in industry to get to full competence.

In particular, after taking EE16AB, you really should consider taking the "Critical Making" course as well as others offered in the Jacobs design program. These can bring you closer to your goal of being able to build things. The key thing is that while EE16AB help you better conceptualize engaging informationally with the physical world and the constraints/possibilities that exist, it does not really expose you to many of the real-world challenges and perspectives that arise from the fact that you build things out of components and modules that you must choose. Other courses and experiences help you with that critical dimension.

Well, a huge part of building something on your own is learning new things, so I don't think you're "underprepared" to build something from scratch.

For software projects, I recommend reading through these: https://knightlab.northwestern.edu/2014/06/05/five-mini-programming-projects-for-the-python-beginner/

For hardware, maybe do something with Raspberry Pi? https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinion/best-raspberry-pi-projects-pi-3-pi-zero-2949390

children.subject: 10000% second Professor Sahai's suggestion of taking Critical Making, it's an incredibly important course in terms of understanding principles of engineering, and what great solutions, problem solving and thinking looks like. In general would also recommend just joining a lab, either industry or research at  Cal. You can get tons of hands on experience with the amazing EE faculty here, literally show up and show a degree of commitment [rule of thumb: read papers and google texts that have interesting material, even if you don't get it at all] and you'll have a great time.

history.content:
Kind of a kidding, not kidding question, but I want to build something. I know it's vague but that's it. And I'm planning on taking EE16A/B to accomplish this goal of building something, whatever that something might be, but I want to get the opinion of someone who has taken these courses of whether or not these will be enough.

For more context, say I want to build a remote control car, a toaster, an iPhone 12? EE16A/B enough?
history.subject: I Want To Build Something. EE16A/B Enough?
